head.title: Reinventing John Jay Or Merely Redistricting?

hedline.hl1: Reinventing John Jay Or Merely Redistricting?

block.p: Re ''The Quest to Reinvent John Jay'' (Sept. 24): District 15's plan to improve John Jay High School to attract Park Slope students is admirable. But let's face it: if successful, it would not be because of its highfalutin educational programs, but rather because troublemaking, academically deficient students from far-off neighborhoods would be redirected to other schools.

John Jay's problems have simply been a result of too many of these students, which no high school could be expected to turn into well-behaved high achievers. The proposal for John Jay seeks to replace these difficult teenagers with a lower number of Park Slope high schoolers and District 15 middle schoolers.

Re ''The Quest to Reinvent John Jay'' (Sept. 24): District 15's plan to improve John Jay High School to attract Park Slope students is admirable. But let's face it: if successful, it would not be because of its highfalutin educational programs, but rather because troublemaking, academically deficient students from far-off neighborhoods would be redirected to other schools.

John Jay's problems have simply been a result of too many of these students, which no high school could be expected to turn into well-behaved high achievers. The proposal for John Jay seeks to replace these difficult teenagers with a lower number of Park Slope high schoolers and District 15 middle schoolers.

I applaud the John Jay plan because it might save local students from having to schlep to far-off high schools, as I did in the 1980's despite living just two blocks from John Jay. However, I regard the plan as simple redistricting wrapped in a fancy package.
